caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of different methods for open-loop planning performance on the nuScenes dataset.  It shows various metrics such as L2 error (distance error), collision rate, intersection rate with road boundaries, and frames per second (FPS). The methods are compared using different evaluation protocols (TemAvg and NoAvg) to ensure fairness.  The table includes both LiDAR-based and vision-based methods, highlighting the performance of the proposed UAD method.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of the open-loop planning performance of various methods on the nuScenes dataset.  The metrics used are L2 error, collision rate, intersection rate, and Frames Per Second (FPS).  Different evaluation protocols (TemAvg and NoAvg) are compared, and the impact of using ego status in the planning module is also shown.  The table highlights the superior performance of the proposed UAD method compared to other state-of-the-art methods.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of open-loop planning performance on the nuScenes dataset [2] among various methods.  Metrics include L2 error (average distance between predicted and ground truth trajectory), collision rate (percentage of trajectories resulting in collisions), intersection rate (percentage of trajectories intersecting road boundaries), and frames per second (FPS).  Different methods use different data and evaluation protocols (indicated by TemAvg and NoAvg).  The table highlights the proposed method's (UAD) superior performance across all metrics.

caption: Table 6: Ablation on the angular design.
description: This table presents the ablation study on the angular design of the proposed UAD method. It compares the performance metrics (L2 error and collision rate at 1s, 2s, and 3s prediction time steps) between the UAD model with angular design and the one without.  The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the angular design in improving the model's performance.

caption: Table 8: Ablation on the 3D detection head.
description: This ablation study investigates the impact of adding a 3D detection head to the UAD model.  The table compares the performance metrics (L2 error and collision rate) with and without the additional 3D detection head, showing the impact on the model's robustness and performance.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details). means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of the open-loop planning performance of various methods on the nuScenes dataset [2].  The metrics used are L2 error (average distance between predicted and ground truth trajectories), collision rate (percentage of collisions), intersection rate (percentage of intersections with road boundaries), and FPS (frames per second). The table shows that the proposed UAD method achieves superior performance across all metrics compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of various methods for open-loop planning in the nuScenes dataset.  Metrics include L2 error (distance between predicted and ground truth trajectory), collision rate (percentage of collisions), intersection rate with road boundaries (percentage of intersections with road boundaries), and frames per second (FPS). Different methods are compared, including those using LiDAR data and those using only cameras.  The table highlights the performance of the proposed method (UAD) in comparison to other state-of-the-art approaches.

caption: Table 11: Ablation on different backbones and pre-trained weights.
description: This table presents the ablation study on different backbones (ResNet50 and ResNet101) and pre-trained weights (None, ImageNet, COCO, and NuImages).  The results show the average L2 error and collision rate for different settings, demonstrating the impact of backbone architecture and pre-training on the model's performance.  FPS values indicate the inference speed for each configuration.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of open-loop planning performance across several state-of-the-art methods on the nuScenes dataset.  Metrics include L2 error (average distance between predicted and ground truth trajectories), collision rate (percentage of trajectories resulting in a collision), intersection rate (percentage of trajectories intersecting road boundaries), and frames per second (FPS). The table highlights the performance of the proposed method (UAD) against various baselines, showcasing its superior performance in terms of lower errors and collision rates, while maintaining a higher FPS.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details).  means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of different methods for open-loop planning in the nuScenes dataset.  The metrics used for comparison include L2 error (the average distance between the predicted and ground truth trajectory), collision rate (percentage of times the predicted trajectory collides with obstacles), intersection rate (percentage of times the predicted trajectory intersects road boundaries), and FPS (frames per second, a measure of inference speed). The table shows that the proposed UAD method outperforms other methods across all metrics while maintaining a high FPS.

caption: Table 1: Open-loop planning performance in nuScenes [2]. † indicates LiDAR-based method and denotes TemAvg evaluation protocol used in VAD and ST-P3 (see Eq. 9 for details). means using ego status in the planning module and calculating collision rates following BEV-Planner [26].
description: This table presents a comparison of different methods for open-loop planning in the nuScenes dataset.  Metrics include L2 error (distance error between predicted and ground truth trajectories), collision rate (percentage of collisions with the environment), intersection rate (percentage of intersections with road boundaries), and frames per second (FPS).  The table compares various methods, highlighting the performance of the proposed UAD method against state-of-the-art techniques. Different evaluation protocols (TemAvg and NoAvg) are also considered to account for variations in how these metrics are calculated.
